important_phrase: Above normal rainfall soaked most District farm areas
Price pressures remained relatively stable throughout the District
However, the pace of layoffs appears to have slowed, as fewer firms reported layoffs than earlier in the year
Several business contacts reported difficulty meeting financing needs because of restricted availability of credit
Most regional manufacturers indicated that the rate of decline in production and orders had moderated in April
Homebuilders noted that new home inventories were trending down on a year-over-year basis as construction remained at low levels and new home sales improved modestly
Most regional auto dealers noted further declines in sales, with several pointing to reduced credit availability and industry uncertainty as reasons for the poor results
Retailers are the exception, with a majority of respondents reporting modest sales increases from a year ago
Despite the improvement over prior months, there is still a marked decline from the previous year, with yearly revenues down 10 percent to 50 percent
On average, they appear fairly stable
Despite favorable interest rates, low prices, and the first-time homebuyer tax credit, contacts say concerns about employment and the overall economy are still holding back the market
Prices remain stable
Also, the emergence of corn and soybean plants lagged normal rates across much of the District
Credit conditions improved, but remained tight for some firms
Prices declined further for inputs such as steel
Credit conditions in the District improved in April and May, but remained tight for some firms
The pace of business spending slowed in April and May
However, residential real estate conditions improved some from the previous reporting period
Inventories were indicated to be very low in anticipation of sluggish sales
Prices paid for production equipment and materials were stable to declining
Core deposits grew strongly
Other types of consumer lending were characterized as stable, with little change in loan pricing
For the most part, raw materials prices and product pricing were stable or declined, and little inflationary pressure is expected during the next 12 months
W heard numerous reports of difficulties in obtaining financing that resulted in some projects being delayed or shut down
Accounts from auto dealers indicate that new vehicle sales slowed during the past few weeks, while purchases of used vehicles showed a modest improvement

Contacts in the natural gas industry noted productive shales in Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and Pennsylvania and increased efficiency due to new technology may mean a reduced need for operating rigs going forward
Labor market conditions remain soft as firms continue to implement hiring freezes in the face of uncertainty
Retailers said selling prices were mostly steady, although prices of "day-to-day" goods continued to fall
Contacts report a slowdown in consumer loan demand, specifically credit card purchase volume
High-tech manufacturing contacts reported orders had improved slightly since the last survey
Home starts remain at very low levels, but outlooks suggest a pickup as inventories have been greatly reduced
Outlooks remain quite uncertain and most respondents don't expect any solid improvement until 2010
Global weather concerns underpinned higher crop prices
The Tenth District economy declined at a slower pace in April and May with firmer expectations of improvement going forward
Manufacturers reported a slower decline in raw materials prices since the last survey period, and prices were expected to ease further
Overall loan demand was relatively unchanged after decreasing moderately in the previous survey
After steady declines in previous months, export orders fell at a slower pace in May
Commercial real estate activity weakened further and was expected to remain sluggish
Mall and restaurant contacts reported slower traffic and a reduction in the average amount spent
Strms caused havoc on calving, as many contacts reported significantly higher than normal deaths
Price increases remained subdued
Wge increases were modest
Manufacturing activity decreased since the last report
Commercial real estate activity was very slow
Consumer spending remained soft, but improved somewhat from the previous few months
Wnd energy projects expanded in the Kansas City and Minneapolis Districts
Manufacturing activity declined or remained at a low level across most Districts
Richmond's retail prices continued to rise, albeit more slowly than in the past
Most Districts reported that overall lending activity was stable or weak, but with mixed results across loan categories
Manufacturing declined or remained weak in most Districts
However, Chicago reported that inventories remain elevated
Business at Manhattan hotels and Broadway theaters, which had increased modestly in April, fell back in May

Finally, bankers again report increased demand for home mortgages but steady to somewhat weaker demand in other loan categories; they also report further tightening in credit standards and continued moderate increases in delinquency rates across all segments

Small to medium-sized banks in the District report mixed results on loan demand: increased demand is again noted in the residential mortgage category; demand for loans in the commercial and industrial loan category decreased, while demand for consumer loans and commercial mortgages held steady

Contacts in the District's manufacturing sector report that conditions have generally stabilized since the last report, and a majority foresee improvement in business conditions over the next six months
Commercial real estate markets in the District were steady to weaker since the last report
Retail sales were reported to be roughly on plan in May but still down moderately from a year earlier, with selling prices holding fairly steady overall
The outlook in the Third District improved slightly in May
Construction firms said the prices of most building materials have been steady, although there have been recent increases for a limited number of products
The slowness in business lending reflected a general slowdown in expansion by firms, according to bank lending officers, as well as what one described as "a lack of credit-worthy business borrowers
The outlook among Third District manufacturers is positive despite the current weakness, and the level of optimism has improved since the last Beige Book
Economic uncertainty has prompted "short-term transactions, downsizing, and consolidation of existing spaces," according to one contact
" Retailers in the region generally do not expect a strong improvement in sales during the rest of this year
However, rain and below-average temperatures hindered soybean and peanut plantings in South Carolina, while pasture conditions in the state improved notably
Contacts at District ports observed weak conditions, but noted signs of potential improvement
Another agent in the Raleigh area anticipated stronger demand due to the improvement in confidence in the business community
Commercial loan rates were flat to slightly higher, with contacts reporting floors added to variable rates
Services firms cut workers and average wages were lower
In commercial real estate markets, leasing activity increased modestly since our last report, although it continued at a slow pace
Retail price growth slowed since our last report
Demand remained largely stable for agricultural producers and somewhat weak for providers of natural resources
Loan demand weakened further on net and credit availability remained tight
Gasoline prices rose modestly but remained well below last year's highs
Contacts attributed declines in business and consumer loan volumes primarily to the limited number of qualified applicants, but they also noted that lending standards remained relatively stringent

By contrast, conditions improved further for manufacturers of semiconductors and other information technology products, as new orders and sales increased modestly, capacity utilization rose, and inventories were brought into balance
However, the pace of home construction remained very slow
Unit sales of gasoline were running slightly below their levels from 12 months earlier
The average rating for pastures in the District states was slightly better, while the average rating for winter wheat was slightly worse than the same time last year
Overall lending at a sample of large District banks decreased moderately during the first quarter of 2009
Credit standards for consumer loans ranged from unchanged to tightened somewhat, while demand varied slightly from weaker to moderately stronger
Several manufacturers reported plans to close plants and reduce operations in the near future
Downtown office vacancy rates remained fairly constant in St Louis, Louisville, and Little Rock but increased slightly in Memphis
Lawn and garden products were strong sellers, while bedroom furniture moved more slowly
